channel.title: Financial Modelling on Alexey Smirnov

item.title: Calculating enterprise value with Python and Pandas (part 2). WACC and DCF
item.description: The latests documentation for pyfinmod is available here https://pyfinmod.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ The weighted average cost of capital (WACC) is used as the discount rate for a firm’s anticipated free cash flows (FCFs) The formula is the following: whereE = market value of the firm’s equity D = market value of the firm’s debtTc = firm’s corporate tax raterE = firm’s cost of equityrD = firm’s cost of debt

item.title: Calculating enterprise value with Python and Pandas (part 1). FCF
item.description: The latests documentation for pyfinmod is available here https://pyfinmod.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ Enterprise Value Value of the enterprise may be used to find out whether the price of company equity - a share - is worth what market offers. It’s also used in acquisitions to get the price of the company as a whole. In this post I’ll cover 3 methods of Enterprise Value calculations: using accounting book efficient market approach discounted cash flows (DCF) The latter one - DCF - is a complex topic.

item.title: Basic Financial Calculations with Python and Pandas
item.description: The latests documentation for pyfinmod is available here https://pyfinmod.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ In this post I’ll cover: Net present value (NPV) Internal rate of return (IRR) Payment schedules and loan tables Future value Pension and accumulation problems Continuously compounded interest Net present value Present value allows to answer a simple question “should I put my money in a bank or invest”. Let’s say I have $100 and the bank gives a 12% annual interest rate.
